title: UK Settles Torture Complicity Case with Guantanamo Detainee
summary: The UK government has provided substantial compensation to Abu Zubaydah, a detainee at Guantanamo Bay who was tortured by the CIA and has been imprisoned without trial for nearly two decades. Zubaydah was subjected to enhanced interrogation techniques after 9/11, initially labeled a senior al-Qaeda member, though the US later retracted this claim. UK intelligence agencies MI5 and MI6 contributed to his mistreatment by supplying questions to the CIA during interrogations, despite awareness of the torture. Zubaydah filed a legal claim against the UK, alleging complicity in his torture, leading to a financial settlement. His international legal counsel, Prof Helen Duffy, emphasized that while the compensation is significant, it is inadequate, urging the UK and other governments to secure his release as violations of his rights persist. The Foreign Office declined to comment, citing intelligence matters, and the exact compensation amount remains confidential for legal reasons. Dominic Grieve, who chaired a parliamentary inquiry, described the settlement as unusual but acknowledged the wrongdoing. Zubaydah, a Palestinian born in Saudi Arabia, has been detained at Guantanamo since 2006 without charge, among 15 remaining prisoners despite documented abuse.

background_read: This article discusses the case of Abu Zubaydah, a detainee at Guantanamo Bay who was tortured by the CIA using enhanced interrogation methods after the 9/11 attacks. Initially accused of being a senior al-Qaeda member, this allegation was later withdrawn by the US. UK intelligence services, MI5 and MI6, were complicit by supplying questions for his interrogations despite knowledge of the torture. Zubaydah brought a legal claim against the UK for complicity, resulting in a substantial financial settlement. Prof Helen Duffy, his legal counsel, argues that while compensation is important, it is insufficient, and his ongoing detention without trial constitutes continuous human rights violations. The UK Foreign Office has not commented, and the settlement amount is secret. Dominic Grieve, who led a parliamentary inquiry, noted the unusual nature of the settlement but affirmed the wrongdoing. Zubaydah remains one of 15 prisoners at Guantanamo, highlighting issues of justice and accountability in counter-terrorism efforts.
